intro: Cynoctonum scoparium, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a shrub native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Asparagaceae and is characterized by its stiff, fibrous leaves that are used for making traditional textiles. The plant typically grows in coastal and lowland areas, thriving in well-drained soils. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are usually green or white in color. Due to its historical and cultural significance, it is an important species in Māori traditions and ecological restoration projects.
